_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Manual dilution with water in the event of small leak or residue only
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Prevention Program Description



Zeco Inc. stores sanitation, soaps and intervention chemicals used in the food safety industry.  These chemicals are used throughout the industry for many different applications such as general cleaning of equipment and bacterial intervention.  Intervention involves the use of Peracetic acid applied to protein carcass to eliminate bacteria and other pathogens that could potentially cause harm to the public.  

Peracetic acid is delivered by truck in individual vented IBC totes and L99 HMWPE Resin drums to the warehouse storage location. Product is off loaded by forklift and staged in one location within the warehouse awaiting purchase, pickup and delivery.  

Zeco uses trained fork lift operators to move the product throughout the process.  The product containers are not opened for any reason.  Zeco employees do not perform emergency response actions.  In the event a spill should occur, all employees are instructed to evacuate and notify the local fire department.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



    Zeco Inc. is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by prioritizing environmental health and safety within its daily operations.  The commitments are documented in the revised company safety policies and procedures.  Zeco management stresses safe operations in employee training programs which include refresher training and updates to any changes made in the industry.



Description of Process



     Zeco Inc. stores sanitation, soaps and intervention chemicals used in the food safety industry.  These chemicals are used throughout the industry for many different applications such as general cleaning of equipment and bacterial intervention.  Intervention involves the use of Peracetic acid applied to protein carcass to eliminate bacteria and other pathogens that could potentially cause harm to the public.  

Peracetic acid is delivered by truck in individual vented IBC totes and L99 HMWPE Resin drums to the warehouse storage location. Product is off loaded by forklift and staged in one location within the warehouse awaiting purchase, pickup and delivery.  The process is a basic inbound delivery with staging of the product and then re-loading for outbound deliveries to the customer.

Zeco uses trained fork lift operators to move the product throughout the process.  The product containers are not opened for any reason.  Zeco employees do participatein emergency response actions and have trained to do so.  Zeco has spills available at all times and all employees go through a class room training, followed by a spill demonstration.  Zeco installed new technology, called a Steri-trac system of monitoring the PPM in the air to alert employees of a potential leak.   In the event a spill should occur,  the shipping employees are trained to stop a small leak of 10 gallons.  In the event of a large uncontrolled release of a tote, employees are instructed to evacuate and cover the storm drains to prevent any release fro

m outside the property of occurring.  Also, the employees will notify the local fire department and call Safety Kleen to help with the spill clean up.  



Worst Case Scenario



    An accidental release of the total amount of Peracetic Acid stored is believed to be unlikely due to the individual co-located storage methods used.  Potential total release would be in the event of natural disaster, fire, or structural collapse.  The calculated endpoint is 2.3 miles with public receptors within the distance to the endpoint.  The facility contains a 24 hour monitored fire alarm system in which the Chattanooga Tennessee Fire Department would respond in case of emergency.



Alternative Release



    Potential release of Peracetic Acid is determined to be by fork truck operator error by means of puncturing the product container with the forks of the mobile unit.  Estimation of the forks entering the lowest point of the container, with a release rate of 16.6 lbs/min at release duration of 6160 mins was calculated.  In the event of such release, all employees are instructed on how to contain such a leak and call Safety Kleen to provide support if needed.  The local fire department will also be contacted.



Maintenance



    Pre-shift inspections are performed by the fork truck operator.  Any deficiency is noted and put on schedule for repair.  If any deficiency is found to compromise the safe operation of the unit, the unit is placed out of service and scheduled for repair.  It is not permissible to alter or disable any safety feature placed on the unit by the manufacturer.  Material KENCO of Chattanooga TN is contracted to perform maintenance and repairs on the fork trucks keeping the units safe to operate.



Training



       Required annual safety training is performed in coordination of current written safety programs. Written safety programs and policies were updated in 2014 to reflect changes in requirements and best practices in the industry. All employees are required t

o undergo general safety training and function specific training prior to beginning the job.  Management is always open to and seeking new techniques and methods to improve the overall safety, and reducing any environmental impact of our process.
